inlineContent.text: In this tutorial, you’ll create a simple smart contract that manages a counter. Users can increment or decrement the counter, and the changes are persisted across contract executions.
Before writing the contract, set up the project using the SpaceKit command-line tool.
This command generates a new folder named “Counter.”
Navigate to your desired directory and execute the command
In this tutorial, Xcode is used. If using other environments, consult their respective guides.
Open the “Counter” directory in your preferred Swift IDE. Xcode or VSCode (with the official Swift extension) are recommended.
(Optional) Build the project for improved IDE performance and macro generation.
Let’s write the code for the smart contract.
Only the SpaceKit library is compatible with SpaceVM. Avoid importing Foundation or other frameworks.
Import the SpaceKit framework by adding
at the top of the file.
You can define multiple controllers in a single or multiple files. A contract consists of all the controllers declared.
Define the contract by creating a struct annotated with
Add a storage property to persist the counter using
type to handle arbitrarily large numbers.
endpoint to increment the counter. This endpoint accepts a parameter specifying the increment amount.
type prevents negative values. If a decrement results in a negative value, the operation fails without any changes.
This function does not modify the contract’s state, that’s why we call it “view”.
The initializer is a global function executed once during deployment. It is optional.
Add an initializer to set the initial counter value during contract deployment.
Test your contract using SpaceKit’s SwiftVM emulator.
directory. Replace any files with a new file named
XCTest is the official framework for unit tests in Swift.
Define the contract address. SwiftVM assigns a deterministic address for your contract.
Create a test class inheriting from
to define the contract address in SwiftVM.
Write a unit test for deploying the contract with an initial counter value of zero.
This calls your @Init function if defined and captures any deployment errors.
The instantiated controller includes, on each endpoint, optional parameters to mock transaction data.
Verify the counter’s initial value with the
Add a unit test to verify deploying the contract with a non-zero initial value.
Create unit tests for the increase endpoint, similar to the deployment tests.
Add a test to ensure failure when trying to decrease the counter below zero.
Run the tests to confirm your contract works correctly!

abstract.text: SpaceKit provides types that allow you to leverage the full potential of the SpaceVM.

Blockchain platforms using SpaceVM enable seamless execution within a sharded environment. Sharding divides a blockchain’s global state and validation workload into smaller, manageable units known as shards. This method enhances scalability without compromising decentralization, allowing nodes to operate without significant computational resources.

doc://SpaceKit/tutorials/SpaceKit/Unders.title: Issuing a Semi-Fungible Token from Your Contract

abstract.text: Learn about the ESDT standard used in the SpaceKit framework, a token model that supports fungible tokens, non-fungible tokens (NFTs), semi-fungible tokens, and meta-esdt tokens.
The SpaceKit framework uses a token standard called ESDT. This standard defines four types of tokens: fungible, non-fungible (NFT), semi-fungible, and meta-esdt.
Before writing your first smart contract with SpaceKit, ensure you have the necessary tools installed.
SpaceKit provides types that allow you to leverage the full potential of the SpaceVM.

CodingFirstContractSection3Step14.png.alt: Xcode's test tab showing all tests passed.

abstract.text: Each time a smart contract is invoked, it runs a single operation. The contract is temporarily loaded into the SpaceVM memory, the operation is executed, and then the contract is removed from memory.

Blockchain platforms using SpaceVM enable seamless execution within a sharded environment. Sharding divides a blockchain’s global state and validation workload into smaller, manageable units known as shards. This method enhances scalability without compromising decentralization, allowing nodes to operate without significant computational resources.
Learn about the ESDT standard used in the SpaceKit framework, a token model that supports fungible tokens, non-fungible tokens (NFTs), semi-fungible tokens, and meta-esdt tokens.
The SpaceKit framework uses a token standard called ESDT. This standard defines four types of tokens: fungible, non-fungible (NFT), semi-fungible, and meta-esdt.

doc://SpaceKit/tutorials/SpaceKit/Unders.title: Issuing a Fungible Token from Your Contract

abstract.text: Non-fungible tokens (NFTs) are unique digital assets that cannot be interchanged. Each NFT is associated with a unique identifier, known as a nonce. You can think of it like an airline ticket—each ticket is assigned to a specific passenger, with individual preferences and details.

The ESDT standard enables embedding custom data within non-fungible tokens, allowing developers to extend the functionality of their smart contracts. This additional data, referred to as “attributes,” is tied to the token and transfers along with it between wallets.

The ESDT standard enables embedding custom data within non-fungible tokens, allowing developers to extend the functionality of their smart contracts. This additional data, referred to as “attributes,” is tied to the token and transfers along with it between wallets.

The ESDT standard enables embedding custom data within non-fungible tokens, allowing developers to extend the functionality of their smart contracts. This additional data, referred to as “attributes,” is tied to the token and transfers along with it between wallets.
Fungible tokens function similarly to traditional currencies, making them the simplest type of token to work with.

Non-fungible tokens (NFTs) are unique digital assets that cannot be interchanged. Each NFT is associated with a unique identifier, known as a nonce. You can think of it like an airline ticket—each ticket is assigned to a specific passenger, with individual preferences and details.

doc://SpaceKit/tutorials/SpaceKit/Operat.title: Assign Create, AddQuantity, and Burn Roles

abstract.text: Fungible tokens function similarly to traditional currencies, making them the simplest type of token to work with.

Smart contracts can interact not only with users but also with other smart contracts. This enables more advanced protocols by leveraging existing ones. For example, you could integrate a decentralized exchange directly into your contract to perform token swaps. Decentralized applications often involve multiple contracts, each with a dedicated role, working together to achieve complex functionality—similar to microservices in backend systems.

Many smart contracts rely on contextual data to execute their operations effectively. This data can include input payments, the caller’s address, the current time, the balance of a specific account, or even the contract owner.

The ESDT standard enables embedding custom data within non-fungible tokens, allowing developers to extend the functionality of their smart contracts. This additional data, referred to as “attributes,” is tied to the token and transfers along with it between wallets.

doc://SpaceKit/tutorials/SpaceKit/TokenA.title: Enhance Your Contracts with Token Attributes
